text: Lordstown Motors Corporation is an American automobile manufacturer of electric vehicles. Lordstown Motors is located in Lordstown, Ohio, United States, in the former Lordstown Assembly which previously belonged to General Motors. == History == Lordstown Motors Corporation was founded by Steve Burns, former CEO of Workhorse Group, based in Loveland, Ohio, which developed battery electric powertrains for UPS delivery trucks (United Parcel Service). On November 7, 2019, Lordstown Motors became the owner of the former GM Lordstown plant, after signing a sales agreement with automaker General Motors in May 2019. GM loaned Lordstown Motors in 2019 to underwrite a substantial part of the plant purchase.The Osborne Effect: Why Big Auto Is Lying To You | In Depth, Now You Know, at 21:30, 17 July 2020, accessed 24 July 2020. On August 3, 2020, Lordstown Motors announced that they will merge with a special-purpose acquisition company (SPAC) named DiamondPeak Holdings. The merged company will trade on the NASDAQ under the symbol RIDE. The merger would give Lordstown Motors an estimated equity value of $1.6 billion dollars which includes $75 million worth of investment from General Motors. The merger is expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2020. == Vehicles == The Lordstown Endurance is an in-development all-wheel-drive, electric pick-up (double cabin with separate bucket).
